The_Jenkins:
{{Short description|American country music group}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Jenkins | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Sebastopol, California]], United States | genre = [[country music|Country]] | years_active = 2004-2008 | label = [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] | current_members = Brodie Jenkins
Kacie Jenkins
Nancy Jenkins }} '''The Jenkins''' were an American [[country music]] group comprising Nancy Jenkins and her daughters, Kacie and Brodie. The trio had two singles in the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts: "Blame It on Mama" at No. 34 and "Getaway Car" at No. 38. The latter was later a single for [[Hall & Oates]]. An album was recorded for [[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]] but never released. ==Biography== Nancy Jenkins and her daughters began to perform together when she started to produce the annual talent show at Kacie and Brodie's school.[https://web.archive.org/web/20040706045314/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/jenkins/bio.jhtml CMT.com : The Jenkins : Biography] When Kacie was in sixth grade, the three performed [[The Judds]]' song "Guardian Angels" in a school production. Dennis Hysom, a local songwriter, who attended the show persuaded Nancy and her daughters to pursue a career as a country music trio. The three then recorded a [[demo tape]], with Nancy writing some of the songs.[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p657414/biography|pure_url=yes}} AllMusic ((( The Jenkins > Biography )))] In 2003, the trio was signed to Capitol Records, working with singer-songwriter and record producer [[Rodney Crowell]] on the first album, to be called ''The Jenkins''.[http://netmusiccountdown.com/inc/artist.php?artist=The+Jenkins Net Music Countdown : The Jenkins] "Blame It on Mama" was released as an advance single in early 2004; the song was a minor top 40 hit in the ''Billboard'' U.S. [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. A second single, "Getaway Car", was released but the album itself was never released. "Getaway Car" was originally recorded by [[4 Runner]] on their album ''Getaway Car'', and was later a hit in the [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks]] charts when [[Hall & Oates]] recorded it. The Jenkins left Capitol in 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1585038/country-labels-keep-rosters-full-despite-album-sales-dip/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218124957/http://www.cmt.com/news/1585038/country-labels-keep-rosters-full-despite-album-sales-dip/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 18, 2014|title=Country Labels Keep Rosters Full Despite Album Sales Dip|first=Edward|last=Morris|website=CMT News}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Single ! colspan="1"| Peak positions ! rowspan="2"| Album |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="65"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]] |- | rowspan="2"| 2004 ! scope="row"| "Blame It on Mama" | 34 | align="left" rowspan="2"| ''The Jenkins'' (unreleased) |- ! scope="row"| "[[Getaway Car (Susan Ashton song)|Getaway Car]]" | 38 |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" !
